B-meson decays involving b → u transitions are sensitive to the Unitarity Triangle angle α (or
φ2 ). The B-factories at SLAC and KEK have made significant progress toward the measurement of
α in recent years. This paper summarizes the results of the B-factories' constraints on α.
PACS numbers: 13.25.Hw, 12.15.Hh, 11.30.Er
Keywords: CP Violation; B-meson decays; α.

I.

INTRODUCTION

CP violation (CP V ) was first seen in the decay of neutral kaons [1]. It was shown some time ago that CP V is a
necessary but insufficient constraint in order to generate a net baryon anti-baryon asymmetry in the universe [2]. In
the ensuing years there has been a tremendous amount of activity by the high energy physics community to better
understand the role of CP V in our model of nature − the Standard Model of Particle Physics (SM).
CP V in the SM is described by a single complex phase in a 3 × 3 quark-mixing matrix, VCKM , called the CKM [3]
matrix:

This review is a summary of the experimental constraints on the Unitarity Triangle angle α obtained from B-meson
decays involving b → u transitions. The CKM angle β is well known and consistent with SM predictions [4]. Any

constraint on α constitutes a test of the SM description of quark mixing and CP V in B-meson decays. A significant
deviation from SM expectation would be a clear indication of new physics. It is possible to obtain a SM prediction
of α from indirect constraints by combining measurements of the CKM matrix elements |Vus |, |Vud |, |Vub |, and |Vcb |,
CPV in mixing from neutral kaons, B-B mixing in Bd and Bs mesons and the measurement of sin 2β from b → ccs
◦
decays. The SM predictions for α are (98.2 ± 7.7)◦ from [5] and (97+13
−19 ) [6].
Measurements of α have recently been performed at the B-factories, the BABAR experiment [7] at SLAC and the Belle
experiment [8] at KEK. The B-factories study the decays of B-mesons produced in the process e+ e− → Υ (4S) → BB,

where BB is either B + B − or B 0 B . The neutral B-mesons are produced in a correlated P-wave state. Until one
of the B-mesons in an event decays, there is exactly one B 0 and one B 0 meson. The main goals of the B-factories
include the study of CP V in B-meson decay, and to over-constrain the position of the apex of the Unitarity Triangle
(ρ, η). The final states of interest for the study of α are B → hh′ , where h = ρ, π. Figure 2 shows the Feynman
diagrams corresponding to the dominant amplitudes contributing to the h+ h′− decays.

Interference between the amplitude for direct decay, and decay after B 0 -B 0 mixing to a h+ h′− final state, results in
a time-dependent decay-rate asymmetry between B 0 and B 0 decays that is sensitive to the CKM angle α. To study
the time-dependent asymmetry with neutral B-mesons, one needs to measure the proper time difference ∆t between
the decay of the two B-mesons in the event. On reconstructing the h+ h′− final state of interest (Brec ), one needs to
determine the flavor of the other B-meson (Btag )2 from its decay products. The time difference between the decays of
the two neutral B-mesons in the event (Brec , Btag ) is calculated from the measured separation ∆z between the Brec
and Btag decay vertices. The Brec decay vertex is determined from the two charged-pion tracks in its final state. The
Btag decay vertex is obtained by fitting the other tracks in the event.
The signal decay-rate distribution of a CP -eigenstate decay, f+ (f− ) for Btag = B 0 (B 0 ), is given by:

the decays under study would be a clear indication of CP V .
In the absence of loop (penguin) contributions in B 0 decays to the CP eigenstate h+ h− , S = sin 2α, and C = 0.
The presence of penguin contributions with different weak phases to the tree level amplitude shift the experimentally
measurable parameter αeff away from the value of α. In the presence of penguin contributions αeff = α + δα(penguin),
S = sin 2αeff , and C can be non zero.
For B 0 decays to ρ+ ρ− , S= SL or ST and C= CL or CT are the CP asymmetry parameters for the longitudinal
and transversely polarized signal, respectively. The decay-rate distribution for B 0 decays to the ρ± π ∓ final state is
more complicated than the above description as ρ± π ∓ is not a CP eigenstate (discussed below).
There are two classes of measurement that the B-factories are pursuing. The main goal is to use SU (2) isospin
relations to relate different hh′ final states and limit δα(penguin) in each of the modes B 0 → π + π − , B 0 → ρ± π ∓ and
B 0 → ρ+ ρ− . In some cases only weak constraints on α are obtained when using SU (2) relations and one must use a
model dependent approach to obtain a significant result.
The remainder of this article describes the isospin analysis used to constrain δα(penguin), and experimental techniques. There is a discussion of the results at the end of the article. Throughout this article, the experimental results
are quoted with statistical errors preceding systematic errors unless otherwise stated.

penguins (EWP) are ignored as they do not obey SU (2) isospin symmetry. EWPs have the same topology as the

The decays B → ρρ are more complicated; one has an isospin triangle relation for each of the three amplitudes in
the final state, one corresponding to the CP even longitudinal polarization and two corresponding to the CP even,
and CP odd parts of the transverse polarization. The ρ± π ∓ final state is not a CP eigenstate. This results in the
need for a pentagon isospin analysis [11] or a Dalitz Plot (DP) analysis of the π + π − π 0 final state [12] to measure α.
There are several assumptions implicitly used in the isospin-based direct measurements of α. The assumptions
common to all decay modes are (i) to neglect EWP contributions and (ii) to neglect other SU (2) symmetry breaking
effects. In addition to this, possible I=1 amplitudes [13] in B 0 → ρ+ ρ− decays are ignored. Several groups have
estimated the correction due to the SU (2) breaking effect of EWP contributions to be O(1.5 − 2)◦ [14, 15]. These
estimates consider contributions from the two EWP operators assumed to be dominant in the effective Hamiltonian.
Some estimates of other expected SU (2) symmetry breaking effects exist, where any correction is estimated to be
much less than the current experimental precision [16].

Continuum e+ e− → qq (q = u, d, s, c) events are the dominant background to B → hh′ decays. Signal Brec

variables are used to further discriminate between signal and continuum background [17].
The flavor of Btag is determined from its final state particles. Both BABAR and Belle characterize the final state
particles of Btag into events where there are leptons, kaons and π-mesons. The charge of these reconstructed tracks
in the final state indicate if Btag is a B 0 or a B 0 . The signal purity varies depending on the momentum and type of
tracks in the final state. Events with leptons in the final state are the cleanest and those with charged kaons in the
final state have less background than those with π-mesons. In addition to this, the probability of assigning the wrong
flavor to Btag increases as the background increases. BABAR separates events into mutually exclusive categories of
events, whereas the Belle combines this information into a single variable r, and tunes event selection in bins of r.
The two approaches are equivalent and are described in more detail in the following references [18, 19].
The ∆t distributions of Equations 5 and 13 are convoluted with a detector resolution description, which differs for
signal and continuum background [19, 20], and also take into account dilution from incorrectly assigning the flavor
of Btag . The signal and background parameters are extracted using an extended unbinned maximum-likelihood fit to
the data for the analyses described here.

One should note that the Belle measurement of B 0 → π + π − constitutes an observation of CP V in this decay at
a level of 5.4σ, and evidence for direct CP V at a level of 4.0σ. This is the second observation of CP V in B-meson

 5
decays, the first being the measurement of a non-zero value for sin 2β from b → ccs decays [4]. The BABAR data
are consistent with the hypothesis of no CP V in this decay. In recent years the two sets of results have started to
converge to a common value, but more statistics are required to resolve the controversy.
The ππ isospin analysis is limited by the value of B(B 0 → π 0 π 0 ). Unfortunately this branching fraction is neither large enough to provide sufficient statistics with the current data set to perform a precision measurement of
δα(penguin), nor small enough to enable a strong bound on this quantity. BABAR have performed an isospin analysis
resulting in |δα(penguin)| < 35◦ (90% C.L.). Belle's data exclude values of α between 19 and 72◦ (95.4% C.L.), and
constrain |δα(penguin)| < 38◦ (95.4% C.L.) [23]. One requires a significant increase in statistics to perform a precision
measurement of α using B → ππ decays. However, it is possible to extract a model dependent constraint on α from
the current results assuming SU (3) symmetry (i.e. exchanging u and s quarks), Gronau and Rosner obtain a value
of α = (107 ± 13)◦ [24].

B → ρρ

H = 0 state corresponds to longitudinal polarization and is CP -even, while neither the H = +1 nor the H = −1 state
is an eigenstate of CP . The longitudinal polarization fraction fL is defined as the fraction of the helicity zero state in

decay B 0 → ρ0 ρ0 has an all charged track final state and it is possible to measure both S and C for the different
CP -eigenstate components of the decay, unlike B 0 → π 0 π 0 decays where one can only measure C.
Given that penguin pollution is small, it is possible to perform an isospin analysis of the longitudinal polarization
of the B → ρρ decays, and use the results of BABAR's time-dependent CP analysis of ρ+ ρ− [27] to constrain α. If
one does this, using the aforementioned assumptions, one obtains α = (100 ± 13)◦ using BABAR data [30]. The error
on α is dominated by |δα(penguin)| < 11◦ (68% C.L.). Belle have recently produced a preliminary measurement of
the polarization, branching fraction and CP parameters of B 0 → ρ+ ρ− [31]. The Belle constraint is α = (87 ± 17)◦ ,
which is slightly weaker than the BABAR result. Both ρρ isospin analyses use the same experimental information for
the decays B 0 → ρ0 ρ0 , and B ± → ρ± ρ0 . Figure 5 shows the (1-C.L.) plot of α corresponding to the isospin analysis
of the longitudinally polarized ρρ data [6]. There is also a non-SM solution for α near 175◦ .
Our knowledge of δα(penguin) is primarily determined from the experimental knowledge of the ρ0 ρ0 and ρ± ρ0
branching ratios. As in the case of B → ππ, our knowledge on α is limited by the penguin contribution. However,
for B → ρρ decays δα(penguin) is sufficiently small to allow the B-factories to perform a meaningful measurement.

C.

B → ρπ

The decays B → ρπ can be analysed in two different ways. The more straightforward approach is to cut away
interference regions of the π + π − π 0 DP and analyze the regions in the vicinity of the ρ resonances. This is the so-called
Quasi-2-body approach (Q2B) and it avoids the need to understand the interference regions. The drawbacks of the
Q2B method are that one looses a lot of statistical power by cutting on the DP, and that interference is unaccounted
for. A corollary of this is that one requires more statistics than the B-factories currently have in order to obtain a
significant constraint from the pentagon isospin analysis of B → ρπ. The alternative is to perform an analysis of
the B → π + π − π 0 DP, accounting for the interference between intersecting ρ resonance bands and other resonant
structures. The Q2B approach has been studied by BABAR and Belle [32, 33], and the first time-dependent DP
analysis has been performed by BABAR [34].

from the structure of the DP. The unique aspect of this result is that there is only a single solution between 0 and
180◦ , and thus a two fold ambiguity on α. As a result this measurement is an important constraint on α, ancillary to
that from B → ρρ.
It is possible to derive a model dependent constraint on α from these data as shown by Gronau and Zupan [36].
One can make several assumptions, including (i) the relative strong phase differences between tree level contributions
for ρ+ π − and ρ− π + being less than 90◦ (ii) SU (3) being exact for penguin amplitudes (iii) neglecting EWP (iv)
neglecting annihilation and exchange diagrams to derive a constraint on α. SU (3) breaking effects are estimated in
this model using CLEO, BABAR and Belle data. When doing this Belle obtains α = (102 ± 11expt ± 15model )◦ . Gronau
and Zupan compute the corresponding result for the BABAR analysis as (93 ± 4expt ± 15model )◦ . There are other
models proposed in the literature, for example [37].

V.

DISCUSSION

◦
The indirect measurements of α from the SM are (98.2 ± 7.7)◦ [5] and (97+13
−19 ) [6] from the UTfit and CKM Fitter
groups, respectively. Direct measurements from the B-factories are in good agreement with these predictions, where
the uncertainty on α from B → hh′ decays is known to O(9◦ ). The precision of this result is dominated by an
isospin analysis of B → ρρ decays, with an important contribution from B → ρπ as the latter result suppresses a
second solution for α near 175◦ . This solution is disfavored at the 1.3σ level by studies of B 0 → π + π − π 0 decays.
The B-factory constraints on α will be improved as additional data are analyzed over the next few years, and these
measurements will start to test the closure of Unitarity Triangle with precision. A significant isospin analysis result

uncertainties. The precision on the model dependent constraints obtained are comparable with the isospin analysis
result from B → ρρ.
